  • Over 95% of Deaf Children are Born to Hearing Parents
  • Lipreaders miss out on up to 90% of the conversation
  • Does Sign Language Impair Speech Development?

item.title: One out of three Deaf kids cannot communicate with their family
item.dc:creator: sonca
item.content:encoded: In a paper published at The Mayberry Laboratory at University of California, San Diego In the study, authors wrote “Even when English grammar is made visually accessible in classrooms... it is still often inaccessible to many deaf children for large portions of the day, especially at home. ...For example, Mayberry et al. (2001) interviewed 24 severely and profoundly deaf 7–15-year-olds with hearing parents... One-third of the children reported that they could communicate with no one in their families because no family member knew or used any kind of signs or sign language with them. Another third reported that they could communicate with only one person in their family, typically the mother. Less than one-third of the children reported that they could communicate with family members through sign. ... in contrast to the speech overheard throughout the waking hours by hearing children.” Read the full paper, “The Input Method”.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Cognitive development in deaf children: the interface of language and perception in neuropsychology

item.title: Over 95% of Deaf Children are Born to Hearing Parents
item.dc:creator: sonca
item.content:encoded: A statistic we commonly see is “90% of Deaf children have hearing parents.” The Sign Language Studies, an academic peer review journal, published a study where they found that in fact, that number is over 95%. In the study, authors wrote “the key demographic to report, other than that the overwhelming majority of deaf and hard of hearing students have hearing parents, is whether the child has one or two deaf parents. The annual survey findings indicate that less than five percent of deaf and hard of hearing students receiving special education are known to have at least one deaf parent, which is less than half of the presumed ten percent.” Read the excerpt published on ERIC. Read the full article in this PDF.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: ERIC - Chasing the Mythical Ten Percent: Parental Hearing Status of Deaf and Hard of Hearing Students in the United States, Sign Language Studies, 2004

item.title: Reflections on Raising a Deaf Child
item.dc:creator: sonca
item.content:encoded:
Mary Kiholm is a retired attorney living in Southern Utah with her husband Gene. Her daughter, now an adult, was born deaf. In this blog, she writes about the experience for other parents like her to read.
"Recently, I have become aware that the old battle between ‘oralists’ and sign language proponents has been heating up. I haven’t been following any of the rhetoric back and forth, but the issue has caused me much reflection about our experience as hearing parents, raising a deaf child. I will try to be as brief as possible and hopefully, subsequent questions and/or comments will be useful to both hearing and deaf parents. My husband and I have had eight children between us. My youngest child was born deaf (a result of German Measles during pregnancy). My husband entered her life at age 6 and legally adopted her when she was 9 years old. So let’s put aside the fairly common effects on a child caused by divorce, re-marriage, etc. and just concentrate on the issues relating specifically to the fact that one child with numerous siblings is deaf. By reason of a 10 year age difference, this deaf child’s upbringing was more like that of an only child. Our deaf child is now an adult. She is a beautiful, well rounded person who functions well in either the hearing or deaf communities. She has a family of her own (two hearing boys) and with her wonderful husband (who is also deaf), run a business which makes them self-reliant. Her situation is no different than that of her hearing siblings. While it gives me pause occasionally, when long periods of time pass that I do not have interaction with each of my children, I recognize that the joy of parenthood is watching them grow into independent, self sufficient adults, experiencing all the things life has to offer. I am going to use her real name - Elise Whitworth (Lisi). She has the ability to make changes to this document and if she objects to her name being used, she can insert a pseudonym. We discovered that Lisi was deaf when she was 10 months old. We were looking for ‘signs’ of problems due to her medical history (i.e, rubella in vitro). She often did not respond when we called to her and we noticed she would be startled if she turned and saw us when she had not know we were present. We were very blessed to have neighbors who were deaf and also educators. This was in 1974, so it was quite rare and extremely fortunate for us. They helped us with the very best audiologists and educated us about deafness as an educational disability. They then introduced us to an early education program which we came to learn was a major key to success. At 18 months of age, Lisi started school, dragging a diaper bag onto the bus every morning. The battle between oral and sign was raging back then as well. We investigated all options and (with the added wisdom of our deaf neighbors) decided to use it all, a ‘whatever works’ approach. Her first educational experience was in a ‘Total Communication Program’ that enlisted oral therapy, whatever natural lipreading skills she possessed, SEE signing, and partial integration with hearing children. Our family made a half-hearted effort to learn SEE signs which helped, and we pretty much had the normal family interaction. The most basic and difficult problem we had was that Lisi took total responsibility for communication instead of demanding that others try harder to communicate. She made it too easy for us to be less helpful than we could have been. We made decisions that were not helpful when we made a move out of the School District where she was doing so well and placed her into an educational program that did not allow her to flourish and negatively affected her emotional growth. Beginning in second grade, she was fully integrated in the regular school system with all hearing peers. She had a little help, but there was virtually no ‘in-service training’ for the teachers or hearing students. She managed to continue to adequately learn scholastically, but she became increasingly introverted, lacking friends and basically very unhappy. When it came time to change from Grammar School to Jr. High (or middle school), we were pushing for more adequate classroom help, which was a major struggle with the School District in which we lived. It finally resulted in the need for a formal demand hearing and while preparing for this hearing, we contacted experts still involved in her first educational program. While waiting for me to meet and discuss an issue at her old school (which only went up to the 5th grade), she had the opportunity to use the school’s TTY machine and have a conversation with a friend she had in that first program (a deaf peer). The absolute joy I witnessed was a wakeup call for us. Everything halted and we looked for a way to re-connect her with a program that more adequately addressed the emotional need to have other peers which whom she could freely communicate. While the transition back was not without some problems (turning her into a ‘social’ monster - disruptive, etc.), they were minor and all it took was a threat to pull her out of the new program and back into a purely scholastic environment. She immediately snapped out of it and settled in. Another change of our residence caused a similarly difficult educational problem when Lisi was just about to become a Senior in High School. We contemplated moving to a state that was infant to deaf education and we were concerned for Lisi’s education. She informed us that she wouldn’t mind because all her friends were graduating anyway, and she was sure she could handle the change for her Senior year. We made the move and things went well for a while, until the novelty wore off and the other youth in her school did not continue to make the additional effort it required to make sure she was ‘getting it.’ Nice kids - how much sensitivity can we expect from teens? She became increasingly withdrawn and became involved with some undesirable company. A major incident caused us to look for another solution which included peer grouping. She comfortably finished High School at the Riverside School for the Deaf and went on to enroll at Gallaudet University where she excelled in Journalism and the written word, disproving the theory that using all that sign language might lessen her ability to learn and utilize English language skills. With hindsight, we can see that it would have been helpful if all the understanding we have gained about hearing parents raising a deaf child, were available at the start. It took Lisi’s whole life experience to give us a true understanding. When talking one day, Lisi shared with me (without a hint of malice), “. . . imagine how you would feel, when there was a family get-together, and you went to your room to read a book because you couldn’t understand what was going on anyway.” Heartbreaking! So what would we do differently? We obviously did a lot of things right - “the proof is in the pudding,” but we could have made it so much easier on her. First and foremost - every single person in the family would have learned to sign fluently. It would have been ASL, not SEE sign. SEE sign is useful I suppose, to help teach grammar, but I’m not sure that emphasizing reading and writing skills doesn’t do that much better than forcing the use of a signing method that is so cumbersome and slow. It is hard to imagine how much Lisi missed out on because her family did not fully understand the inherent problems with not being able to freely communicate. It is understandable why parents would want to restrict their child to the hearing world. It is their world - the world where they feel comfortable. They want their child to feel the same, but ultimately, we have to let our children go - to whatever world they choose, to a world where they feel comfortable and appreciated and loved and respected. For the deaf, that is one in which they can freely communicate. When we, as hearing people learn to sign fluently, we are welcomed and feel comfortable within the deaf community. The deaf, no matter how much effort they expend, can never feel as comfortable in the hearing world. Therefore, because we are lazy, we live two blocks away from our daughter and don’t have much more interaction than we do with our children who live in different states. There is a lot of love shared in our family, but sometimes I think [the lack of interaction is] because we don’t have the constant companionship that takes place in some families. We love each other and are always there for each other, but we take our joy in watching each other progress and experience this precious thing called life. It is full of choices. Our challenge as parents, is to teach them to make good choices for their lives, not make the choices for them."

item.title: When I was the isolated deaf kid
item.dc:creator: sonca
item.content:encoded:
J. Parrish Lewis (MunkyMind), a published author who is Deaf, writes about his teen years.
It was in Junior year that life went downhill. After school, if I didn’t have to go to work, I’d stop by the video store and rent a few movies, back when they were still VHS tapes, pick up a pizza and some soda, then go home and watch them. Otherwise I might watch 6 hours of television.
"When I was in High School, I spent the majority of my time alone, feeling invisible. At lunchtime most days, I’d get a couple packets of Nutty Bars and go to my little space in the Art classrooms, purposefully isolating myself rather than feel invisible in the cafeteria. For the first two years, I at least usually had my older brother after school to hang out with, so my isolation was limited to school hours. We unfortunately went to separate schools, even though we were both deaf kids, because I relied on interpreters while he relied on his hearing aids. When we got home from school, tossing our backpacks on the floor and putting homework off until later, life was pretty good. Life was full of Star Trek: The Next Generation, faux-Army missions in the creek, or exploring the city on our bicycles. By the time he graduated, I still had two years left of High School. When he left for college, and later moved across the country, I was not only losing the time I had with my brother, but also my best friend. It was in Junior year that life went downhill. After school, if I didn’t have to go to work, I’d stop by the video store and rent a few movies, back when they were still VHS tapes, pick up a pizza and some soda, then go home and watch them. Otherwise I might watch 6 hours of television. Most days, I was home alone. On rare occasions, I went out by myself, usually driving my VW Bug to the Columbia Mall or the lake, still feeling invisible. I’d stop by my work on my off days, because I could chat with my co-workers there that actually seemed to like to chat with me. Something about that environment eliminated all the cliques that High School cultivated..."
Read the full blog post at MunkyMind (and check out his books!)

Filler page exists to be a parent page for permalink structure.
This page points to the 'stories' archive.
Do not change the permalink.

item.title: “I cried today” by Helen Mackay
item.dc:creator: sonca
item.content:encoded:
For just a few hours I experienced a little of what it must be like for my deaf daughter in a ‘hearing’ world.
Helen’s family uses New Zealand Sign Language, but the story is so universal we had to include it here.
I cried today. I went to a Deaf community meeting. No interpreter available for signing impaired people like me. I went anyway, keen to know about the new voting options for the local Deaf Society and new club room plans. I took my kids. 1 hearing. 1 deaf. Today. The. Tables. Turned. For just a few hours I experienced a little of what it must be like for my deaf daughter in a ‘hearing’ world. I think I understood about 30-40% of what was being signed. Enough, I think, to fill in the blanks with context. Perhaps as much as my deaf daughter picks up when reliant on lipreading when people don’t sign to her or caption TV. I will never know if I did understand so there’s a nagging doubt I missed something, but I think I’m OK. But it was hard. My head hurt so much it is throbbing, still, even as I write this. I concentrated intently on the signing in front of me, unable to be distracted by kids tapping on my shoulder for me to do something. I simply couldn’t multi-task, I had to focus on the people right in front of me. The note pad in front of me, rendered redundant as I couldn’t take my eyes off the ‘speaker’. The distant but loud noise of a builder banging felt out of sync with what my brain was trying to do visually. I had to close the door to help drown out the background interference. My daughter tells me sometimes she just has to take her hearing aids off at school as she cannot focus with them on “mummy they don’t help, its just noise”. Perhaps this is what I was experiencing inside my brain in reverse. I felt compelled to get up and ‘sign’ to the community about something I felt strongly about. I was nervous. As a sign language beginner, with every sign I made, I was conscious that it was far from perfect and desperate that people would understand me. Perhaps this is the same experience my daughter has when she has to stand up and speak without hearing her own voice. Without knowing whether her words sound right and looking for reassurance from her friends to let her know she has been understood or turning to me for assistance with a word she struggles with – just as I had to fingerspell words I could not sign. I looked to the crowd who supported me by signing the word I was stumbling on. But I was vulnerable. The emotion of it all – the subject I was signing about and the way I felt, the tears dripped! When it came time to leave, my eldest daughter wanted to stay. She was at home. This is not the first time this year I’ve cried at a Deaf community event. A few months ago, it happened twice in a week at events held to celebrate Deaf Aotearoa New Zealand Sign Language week. The first, was a solo outing for me. No kids, no husband. Just me. A special screening of the British Deaf Association film the "Power in Our Hands" hosted by Terry Riley, visiting from England to attend the World Federation of the Deaf - Official Board meeting. It’s a powerful film, complete with captions so people like me can follow. It tells the true story of suppression / oppression of the British Deaf community and the gradual recognition of British Sign Language and deaf culture in British society. The film had captions and the signed introduction by Terry was interpreted. I was challenged by the film but linguistically I was still in my comfort zone. My needs were “accommodated”. However the message of the film was so incredibly powerful it cut me to the core that this might happen to MY daughter. I felt ever so grateful for people like Terry who has been instrumental in the UK to make the deaf voice "heard". He has been instrumental to the British Sign Language Broadcasting Trust who produce wonderful video directly relevant to the Deaf community (and accessible to people like me with subtitles). I resolved, as I powered down the pavement away from the event, that the “power” was indeed “in my hands”. As a parent I have a responsibility to ensure I do everything to make my daughters' lives full, and free from discrimination. And to learn more sign. (My daughter is fluent receptively already and has a full time interpreter in her mainstream school where she is the only Deaf child in a roll of 400+. Our family are all learning to sign). In another event that same week, we went to ‘listen’ to Drisana Levitzke-Gray speak – or should I say sign, to a Deaf community event, about her experiences as Young Australian of the Year. There was an interpreter. Again I was moved to tears and compelled to stand up as she shared her experiences of mainstream schooling, rising above the challenges of isolation and her advocacy for children like my daughter. Her message resonated with me, and both my daughters. Again, I strengthened my resolve to be a ‘hearing’ ally. A partner for good. But today with no captions, no interpreter, no ‘signing aid’ and no voice, I had no “accommodation”. I knew there wouldn’t be any, but I choose to go anyway, just as my daughter has had to do every day this week to her wonderful school (her educational interpreter has been away). Except that she doesn’t have a choice, she must go to school regardless, like tonnes of other deaf & hard of hearing kids that don’t have their needs met either. Perhaps they are Cochlear Implant users, denied teaching assistance as they are “cured”, or with an inability to access sign language lessons because the kids are oral and not on the priority list for sign classes. Perhaps they are hearing aid users who are not ‘quite’ deaf enough, but struggle to piece it all together using a combination of lip-reading and technology. Today, it was just me. Laid bare, in a room of people about the same size as my daughters year 6 class. I felt vulnerable, scared and exhausted as I concentrated to understand and then be understood. The tables turned, on me, today. But you know what, that’s no bad thing. My daughter is deaf. Like many deaf children she was born into a family of hearing parents. Being deafened post-lingually she talks. But she is most at ‘home’ with her deaf friends. They get her. Many many times since she went deaf, I have fought to be sure she has full access and treated equally in society. Today, I cried because I realize how much load this ten year old carries, just to get through the day with a smile, let alone understand and be understood. I’ve done deafness ‘simulations’ before and I thought I ‘got’ it. But today, I really got it. You know the best thing? When I cried, no-one judged me. No-one stopped me and said (or signed) “you can’t do it. I was welcomed, appreciated supported and encouraged. For that, I am truly blessed. You see, regardless of whether some form of ‘technology’ may help my Daughter now or in the future, she is Deaf. She speaks, she signs, she has choice. She’s Deaf and proud, and I am thankful she is growing in her own Deaf confidence. I am sure some people will say that I shouldn’t cry about this stuff, and definitely not in front of my kids. But they hugged me tonight and as I signed “I love you” to my Deaf daughter she said “I love you” back. My hearing daughter did the same. I need to be able to switch in the moment, just as they do daily. To see me struggle too helps them both know, life ain’t easy, but it sure is what you make of it. As I write this, again I cry. But tonight, they are happy tears. I know that my daughter has a community of support who get it much more than me. I too value the friendship and welcome. My hearing daughter also gets to see and play with other children who too have deaf brothers and sisters and that's cool too. To everyone that hesitates to get involved in the “Deaf” community, I offer these words of encouragement. Do it! Let your kids have choice. I know we are all stronger together – Deaf & Hearing. For that, tonight, I give thanks. “Hands wave”. In case you are wondering, I’ve also made a note to myself. I must NOT cry at the next event!

item.title: The Case for Bilingual Deaf Children
item.dc:creator: sonca
item.content:encoded:
UConn Today published an article that tells multiple stories, from the point of view of doctors, research professionals, and an audiologist and their personal stories of interactions with Deaf individuals and perspectives they have encountered.
...CIs have varying degrees of success. ‘It’s not like glasses, where you put them on and you can see perfectly,’ says Lillo-Martin. ‘Electronic hearing is very different from acoustic hearing.’
A $1.2 million National Science Foundation (NSF) CAREER Award, one of the largest in the program’s history, was awarded to study the impact of early language experiences – whether spoken or signed – on how children learn. “Access to two languages is just better than access to one,” says Coppola. “I am all for something that increases kids’ capacities, as long as they get language early. Getting language early is the most important thing.” Read the rest of the article here.
